questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a male patient who recently lost his job and is experiencing persistent irritability, sadness, and worry about the future? He also displays irritability towards his family members. Although he is able to temporarily enjoy watching movies with friends, upon returning home, he experiences the same symptoms.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Adjustment disorder

Adjustment disorder

Definition
  • Excessively distressing emotional or behavioral symptoms that occur in response to a stressor
  • Stressors are mild to moderate, such as financial, medical, or relationship issues

Symptoms
  • Low mood and tearfulness
  • Anxiety
  • Aggression
  • Symptoms lead to impairment and poor functioning
  • Occur within 3 months of the stressor and usually resolve within 6 months of the resolution of the stressor
  • Common in hospitalised patients

Treatment
  • Psychotherapy: Group therapy, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT)
  • Crisis intervention
  • Pharmacotherapy with SSRIs and anxiolytics is not typically employed.

questions.text: A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. Which of the following risks is increased in the newborn? Low APGAR score ADHD Persistent pulmonary hypertension Delayed developmental milestones
questions.explanation:
SSRIs in Pregnancy

Fetal outcomes
  • SSRIs generally do not increase the risk of major congenital malformations, except for paroxetine, which is associated with increased heart defect risks when taken during the first trimester.
  • Late pregnancy SSRI use can lead to Poor Neonatal Adaptation Syndrome (PNAS), which includes irritability, poor muscle tone, sleep problems, crying, irritability, hypoglycemia, and seizures.
  • Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN) is a rare but serious risk.
  • Low APGAR score
  • There is an increased risk of ADHD and autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
  • Delayed Developmental Milestones

Maternal outcomes
  • It may impair platelet function and myometrial contractions, disrupting normal hemostasis and vasoconstriction, which can increase the risk of Postpartum hemorrhage.
  • They can influence serotonin levels and inhibit nitric oxide synthesis, leading to vascular changes that elevate the risk of pre-eclampsia.
  • SSRIs may worsen insulin resistance, increasing the risk of GDM during pregnancy.
  • Minimal amounts of SSRIs are present in breast milk, with no reported harmful effects in breastfed babies.

Safer SSRIs in Pregnancy
  • Citalopram,
  • Sertraline,
  • Escitalopram,
  • Fluoxetine.

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect regarding bipolar disorder?

options.label: A
options.text: It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years

options.label: B
options.text: Type 1 is common in both sexes

options.label: C
options.text: Prevalence in the general population is 1-2%

options.label: D
options.text: Attempt to commit suicide seen in around 15% of people

questions.correct_answer: A. It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years
questions.explanation:
Bipolar disorder

Types

Bipolar I Disorder

Bipolar II Disorder

Characterized by at least 1 episode of mania and 1 episode of depression

Characterized by at least 1 episode of hypomania and 1 episode of depression

M = F (Option B ruled out)

F > M

Age of onset is between 12 - 24 years

Age of onset is slightly higher

Epidemiology
  • Annual incidence is less than 1%.
  • Depressive episodes are more common in women.
  • Women are more prone to mixed episodes and rapid cycling.
  • The prevalence rate (in the general population) of bipolar I disorder is 0 - 2.4%, and the prevalence of bipolar II disorder is 0.3 - 4.8%. (Option C ruled out)
  • Age of Onset:
    • Onset ranges from 5 to 50 years, with a mean age of 30.
    • Prevalence in adolescents rises from 2% at ages 13-14 to 4% by age 18.
  • Socioeconomic Factors:
    • Higher incidence in divorced or single individuals.
    • More common in upper socioeconomic groups and non-college graduates.
  • Suicide attempts are common in bipolar disorder, with about 15% of individuals attempting suicide at some point in their lives. (Option D ruled out)

Genetics
  • Family history increases the risk for mood disorders.
  • 1st-degree relatives have a 10-fold risk of developing bipolar disorder.
  • Genetic overlap with schizophrenia, especially on chromosomes 18q and 22q.

Brain Imaging
  • Increased hyperintensities in subcortical areas (basal ganglia, thalamus) in bipolar I disorder.
  • Imaging studies show increased dopamine transporter levels.
  • Functional imaging shows abnormal brain activation, with hyperactivity in frontal areas and hypoactivity in the amygdala and basal ganglia.

questions.text: Double depression is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Depression with dysth

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a recently diagnosed female patient with mild depression?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Cognitive behavioural therapy

Type of Therapy

Description

Indication

Combination Therapy
  • Pharmacotherapy + Psychotherapy
  • Combines medications (e.g., antidepressants) with psychotherapy for a higher response rate.

Moderate to severe depression

Single Therapy

Psychotherapy alone may be sufficient for mild cases.

Mild depression

Psychotherapy Types

Somatic Treatments
  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
  • Interpersonal Therapy (IPT)
  • Family Therapy
  • Psychoanalytically Oriented Therapy
  • Behavior Therapy
  • Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)
  • Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)
  • Vagal Nerve Stimulation (VNS)
  • Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS)
  • Phototherapy
  • Sleep Deprivation

questions.text: Abrupt stoppage of which of the following drugs causes irritability, rebound anxiety, and insomnia?
questions.explanation:
Venlafaxine

MOA
  • Inhibits reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine (SNRI).
  • Weak inhibition of dopamine reuptake.

Uses

  • Major depressive disorder (MDD)
  • Generalised anxiety disorder (GAD)
  • Social anxiety disorder (SAD)
  • Panic disorder

Side effects

  • Nausea, headache, dry mouth, dizziness, sweating, constipation, insomnia.
  • Cardiovascular: Increased blood pressure (dose-dependent).
  • Neurological: Tremors, agitation.
  • Sexual dysfunction: Decreased libido, delayed ejaculation.
  • Withdrawal Symptoms: Irritability, rebound anxiety, insomnia

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is the least probable in a patient prescribed with escitalopram?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) are a class of drugs primarily used to treat depression and other mental health conditions. They increase serotonin levels in the brain, which helps regulate mood, emotion, and sleep.

Common SSRIs
  • Sertraline
  • Fluoxetine
  • Paroxetine
  • Citalopram
  • Escitalopram
  • Vilazodone (SPARI- Serotonin Partial Agonist and Reuptake Inhibitor)
  • Fluvoxamine (mainly for OCD)

Side Effects

Gastrointestinal

  • Nausea (most common) (Option A)
  • Diarrhea
  • Anorexia
  • Dry mouth
  • Weight gain
  • Constipation (especially with paroxetine)

CNS

  • Anxiety
  • Insomnia
  • Sedation
  • Vivid dreams (Option B)
  • Emotional blunting
  • Seizures (rare)
  • Extrapyramidal symptoms

Sexual Dysfunction

(most common side effect in long-term use)
  • Decreased libido
  • Delayed ejaculation
  • Inhibited orgasm (Option C)

Haematological

  • Impaired platelet aggregation
  • Increased risk of GI bleeding (especially with NSAIDs)

Miscellaneous

  • Hyponatremia
  • Allergic rashes
  • Hyperprolactinemia (leading to galactorrhea or menstrual irregularities)

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is the least probable in a patient prescribed with escitalopram?
questions.explanation:
Escitalopram

Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) increase serotonin levels in the brain, which helps regulate mood, emotion, and sleep.

Side Effects

Gastrointestinal

  • Nausea (most common) (Option A)
  • Diarrhea
  • Anorexia
  • Dry mouth
  • Weight gain
  • Constipation (especially with paroxetine)

CNS

  • Anxiety
  • Insomnia
  • Sedation
  • Vivid dreams (Option B)
  • Emotional blunting
  • Seizures (rare)
  • Extrapyramidal symptoms

Sexual Dysfunction

  • Decreased libido
  • Delayed ejaculation
  • Inhibited orgasm - Anorgasmia (Option C)

Hematological

  • Impaired platelet aggregation
  • Increased risk of GI bleeding (especially with NSAIDs)

Miscellaneous

  • Hyponatremia
  • Allergic rashes
  • Hyperprolactinemia (leading to galactorrhea or menstrual irregularities)

questions.text: What is the recommended medical approach for a psychotic patient who experiences voluntary aimless motions and has been observed standing motionless for extended periods with waxy flexibility and negativism?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Lorazepam

Catatonia

Definition
  • It is a psychomotor syndrome characterised by a range of motor, behavioural, and verbal disturbances.
  • It can occur in various psychiatric, medical, and neurological conditions and may present with excessive motor activity or markedly reduced motor activity.

Features
  • Stupor
  • Catalepsy
  • Waxy flexibility
  • Mutism
  • Negativism
  • Posturing: Spontaneous maintenance of a rigid or bizarre posture.
  • Stereotypies: Repetitive, non-goal-directed movements (e.g., hand flapping or grimacing).
  • Mannerisms: repetitive, odd, purposeful movements.
  • Agitation
  • Echolalia or Echopraxia: Repetition of another's words (echolalia) or movements (echopraxia)

Treatment

  • First-line treatment involves benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam), which are effective in alleviating catatonic symptoms.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is also highly effective and often used in patients who do not respond to pharmacotherapy or when rapid resolution is required.

questions.text: A young man with a psychiatric disorder has become very aggressive. He speaks very rapidly and sleeps very little. He exhibits hyperactive behavior after discontinuing his prescribed medication. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Bipolar I Disorder

Bipolar II Disorder

Characterized by at least 1 episode of mania and 1 episode of depression

Characterized by at least 1 episode of hypomania and 1 episode of depression (Option B)

M=F

F>M

Mean age of onset is 30yrs

Mean age of onset is slightly higher

Diagnostic criteria for Mania
  • Mood Changes: Elation/ irritability

+ ≥3 of the following symptoms (4 if irritable mood) for at least 1 week:

  • Distractibility.
  • Impulsivity/ high-risk activities
  • Grandiosity/ Inflated Self-Esteem
  • Flight of Ideas (Racing and expansive thoughts)
  • Activity increased (Hyperactivity)
  • Sleep deficit (decreased need for sleep)
  • Talkativeness/ Pressured speech

questions.text: Which of the following side effects would most likely be caused by a drug that specifically decreases the reabsorption of serotonin?
What is the likely diagnosis for a 10-year-old child experiencing selective mutism?

What diagnosis, according to DSM-,V would be appropriate for a middle-aged female patient who has been experiencing symptoms such as loss of interest in daily activities, weight loss, insomnia, and persistent sadness for a period of six months? Additionally, she reports a single incident of hearing a voice instructing her to commit suicide.

options.label: A
options.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.correct_answer: A. Major depressive disorder with psychotic features
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

Psychotic depression

Definition

Major depression disorder (MDD) with psychotic features includes mood disturbance with delusions, hallucinations, or both.

Prevalence

It occurs in approximately 18.5% of MDD patients and increases with age.

Characteristics
  • Higher treatment resistance
  • More suicide attempts
  • Longer illness duration
  • Greater functional impairment
  • Higher relapse rates

Older patients may exhibit more brain atrophy and higher mortality rates compared to non-psychotic patients.

Geriatric Considerations

Patients often show significant cognitive dysfunction; depressive pseudodementia may develop.

Cognitive Impairment

Combination therapy: antidepressants + antipsychotics or ECT is the standard of care.

Treatment Approaches

Monotherapy with SSRIs or TCAs is less effective.

Efficacy of ECT
  • ECT shows high remission rates (up to 95% in psychotic depression) compared to pharmacotherapy.
  • ECT is first-line treatment in case of severe psychotic symptoms and high suicide risk.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 60-year-old man who is grieving the loss of his wife and expressing guilt, believing his intestines have deteriorated and that he deserves to be imprisoned? He also reports persistent sadness and a lack of interest in daily activities since his wife's passing.
questions.explanation:
Psychotic depression

Definition

Major depression disorder (MDD) with psychotic features includes mood disturbance with delusions, hallucinations, or both.

Prevalence

Occurs in approximately 18.5% of MDD patients and increases with age.

Characteristics
  • Higher treatment resistance
  • More suicide attempts
  • Longer illness duration
  • Greater functional impairment
  • Higher relapse rates

 

Older patients may exhibit more brain atrophy and higher mortality rates compared to non-psychotic patients.

Geriatric Considerations

Patients often show significant cognitive dysfunction; depressive pseudodementia may develop.

Cognitive Impairment

Combination therapy: antidepressants + antipsychotics or ECT is the standard of care.

Treatment Approaches

Monotherapy with SSRIs or TCAs is less effective.

Efficacy of ECT
  • ECT shows high remission rates (up to 95% in psychotic depression) compared to pharmacotherapy.
  • ECT is first line treatment in case of severe psychotic symptoms and high suicide risk.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment option for postpartum blues?
questions.explanation:
Postpartum Blues

Postpartum Depression

Postpartum Psychosis

Occurrence

It affects up to 80% of women after childbirth
  • It affects 10 - 15% of women
  • 70% risk of recurrence in the next pregnancy
  • Incidence is about 1-2 in 1000 deliveries
  • 50% risk of recurrence in the next pregnancy

Timing

Onset 3-5 days postpartum, resolves by days to weeks

Within the first 6 weeks postpartum or after abortion

Symptoms appear within 2-3 weeks postpartum and last 2-3 months.

Symptoms

Transient symptoms such as

  • Emotionally labile
  • Insomnia
  • Weepiness
  • Loss of energy
  • Depressed mood
  • Loss of interest or pleasure (anhedonia)
  • Loss of appetite
  • Insomnia
  • Social withdrawal
  • Irritability
  • Suicidal thoughts

Initial symptoms: insomnia, tearfulness, mood lability, fatigue, followed by

  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions

Treatment

Supportive treatment and reassurance

Antidepressants and psychotherapy
  • Hospitalization, pharmacological treatment (lithium, antipsychotics, antidepressants), long-term psychiatric care
  • Temporary separation from the infant and nursing supervision may be necessary

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 40-year-old man who has been experiencing excessive and uncontrollable worry about daily life activities, finances, and his health for the past two years? He also presents with restlessness, fatigue, disturbed sleep, and waking up once due to a fear that his family was involved in an accident.
Which neurotransmitters are implicated in depression?

questions.text: A patient with low mood, no mood to eat, always sleeping, and low energy presented to you with such symptoms for 2 months. She had similar symptoms 5 months ago, which subsided with medications. Identify the disorder.
questions.explanation:
Disorder

Duration for diagnosis

1. Brief psychotic disorder

1 Day - 1 Month

2. Schizophreniform disorder

< 6 Months

3. Schizophrenia

> 6 Months

4. Schizoaffective disorder

> 14 Days

5. Delusional disorder

> 1 Month

6. Depression

2 Weeks

7. Persistent depressive disorder/ Cyclothymia

2 Years

8. Bipolar disorder/ Mania

1 Week

9. Hypomania

4 Days

10. Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)

2 Weeks

11. Panic disorder

1 Month

12. Generalised anxiety disorder (GAD)

6 Months

13. Phobia

6 Months

14. Acute stress disorder

< 1 Month

15. Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)

> 1 Month

16. Adjustment disorder

< 6 Months

17. Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)

> 6 Months in 2 settings before 12 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes lithium?

options.label: A
options.text: It can cause fine postural tremors at a therapeutic dosage

options.label: B
options.text: It is not absorbed from the gut

questions.correct_answer: A. It can cause fine postural tremors at a therapeutic dosage
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - It can cause fine postural tremors at a therapeutic dosage

Lithium

Mechanism of action

  • Increase the level of amine (if the mood is low) by inhibiting the Glycogen synthase kinase-3 enzyme
  • Decrease the level of amine (if the mood is high)
    • Inhibits inositol monophosphatase enzyme
    • Inhibits the release of amines
    • Stabilises neuronal membrane

Uses

  • Bipolar disorder
  • Hypnic headache (occurs in sleep)
  • Anti-suicidal action (another drug is clozapine)
  • Resistant cases of depression

Adverse effects
  • Alopecia and acne
  • Weight gain
  • Seizures and sinus node dysfunction (leading to AV block)
  • Hypothyroidism (hyperthyroidism in rare cases)
  • High doses can cause coarse tremors, ataxia, tinnitus, diarrhea, and seizures.
  • Ebstein’s anomaly: A cardiovascular defect called tricuspid atresia, which has a teratogenic effect when administered to pregnant women.
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI)
  • Fine tremors (most common adverse effect)
  • ECG changes: T-wave flattening
  • Leukocytosis
  • Loose stools (diarrhea)

questions.text: A 35-years-old patient presents with complaints of sudden and irresistible urges to take action . This is the characteristic of which symptom?
questions.explanation: Correct option A - Impu

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with persistent feelings of sadness, fatigue, loss of appetite and lack of motivation for the past several weeks. On further assessment, the patient reports a decreased interest in activities that were once enjoyable and a general sense of hopelessness. Which of the following is the key symptom of depression?

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of interest in pleasurable activity

questions.explanation: Correct Option B- L

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient on psychiatric medication developed a sudden hypertensive episode after taking wine . He is on antidepressants . Which of the following drug the person be taking?
questions.explanation: Correct option A - MAO inhibitors (monoamine oxidase inhibitors)

questions.text: A patient on amitriptyline was discovered unconscious at home and potentially suspected of TCA toxicity. Which of the following features is less commonly associated with TCA toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Hypothermia:

Mechanism of side effect

Side effect

H1 receptor blockade
  • Sedation, weight gain

Anticholinergic action on muscarinic receptors
  • Hyperthermia (Option C)
  • Dry eyes/mouth
  • Mydriasis (C/I in glaucoma) (Option D ruled out)
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Tachycardia
  • Confusion (Option B ruled out)

Increase in serotonin in the brain
  • Seizure threshold reduction

Alpha 1 adrenergic receptor antagonism
  • Postural hypotension

Sodium channel block
  • Arrhythmia/QT prolongation (Option A ruled out)
  • Bradycardia in heart block due to overdose

questions.text: A pregnant female with bipolar disorder came to the outpatient department in the third trimester. She has had 4 episodes in the past and is stable on lithium 750 mg/day since 1 year, during which time she has not had any episodes. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Stop lithium and let her be drug-free

questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Decrease lithium dosage:

Mood Stabilizers

Medication

Potential Fetal/Newborn risk

Clinical Recommendation

Lithium

 
  • Low risk of Ebstein’s anomaly: 1 in 1000 with first-trimester exposure
  • No evidence of behavioural or cognitive problems in children exposed to lithium till 5 years of age
  • Fetal echocardiography
  • Frequent serum lithium monitor because of fluid shifts over pregnancy
  • Should be well hydrated to reduce chances of lithium toxicity

Valproic acid

 
  • Increased rate of congenital malformations.
  • Linked to neurodevelopmental disorders in children with in-utero exposure
  • Must be avoided in favor of safer agents
  • Before conception, women with BD preferably to be shifted to another safer prophylactic agent
  • High-dose folic acid supplementation (4 mg/day) is advised before conception

Carbamazepine

 
  • Congenital malformations: Neural tube defect, cleft palate, fingernail hypoplasia.
  • Risk of bleeding diathesis in neonates due to Vitamin K deficiency
  • If possible, use in pregnancy should be avoided.
  • High-dose folic acid supplementation (4 mg/day) advised prior to conception
  • Oral Vitamin K (20mg/day) supplementation in the last month of pregnancy in women taking carbamazepine
  • Parenteral Vitamin K (1mg IM) supplementation for newborn shortly after birth.

Lamotrigine

 
  • Risk of major congenital malformations.
  • No significant neurobehavioral sequelae.
  • Preferred safer agent to use in pregnancy.
  • Dose may be increased due to enhanced clearance rates across pregnancy stages.
Other Drugs for Bipolar Disorder Safe in Pregnancy
  • First Generation Antipsychotics (FGA): Haloperidol, Trifluoperazine
  • Second Generation Antipsychotics (SGA): Olanzapine, quetiapine, aripiprazole
  • Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRI): Fluoxetine, escitalopram, sertraline, fluvoxamine

questions.text: A patient on a mood stabilizer has developed hyperammonemia and hepatitis /raised hepatic enzymes. Which of the following is likely to be responsible?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Valproate:

Mechanism of action

  • Sodium Channel Inactivation: Prolongs Na+ channel inactivation in a frequency-dependent manner, similar to phenytoin.
  • Calcium Channel Modulation: Weakly attenuates the T-type calcium currents, akin to ethosuximide.
  • GABA Enhancement: Increases GABA levels by:
    • Inhibiting GABA transaminase, leading to reduced degradation.
    • Possibly enhancing GABA synthesis from glutamic acid.
  • Glutamate Receptor Blockade: Blocks excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors, reducing excitatory neurotransmission.

Uses

  • Seizure Disorders: It is the DOC for atypical absence seizures, myoclonic seizures, and generalised tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS).
  • Mood Disorders: Valproate is effective in the treatment of mania and bipolar disorder.
  • Panic Attacks: It can be used off-label for the treatment of panic attacks.
  • Migraine Prophylaxis: Valproate is considered a second-line treatment for preventing migraines.
  • Mixed Seizure Syndromes: It is used in conditions such as Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • Severe Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy: Valproate is also used in Dravet syndrome

Adverse effects

  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
  • Neurological: Tremor, sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
  • Hepatic: Hepatotoxicity (mainly in children <2 years of age).
  • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia and other blood dyscrasias.
  • Metabolic: Weight gain, hyperammonemia, and pancreatitis.
  • Teratogenicity: Risk of congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects (spina bifida oculta), if used during pregnancy.
  • Others: Hair loss (alopecia) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Valproate is a CYP enzyme inhibitor that inhibits CYP2C9, which can lead to increased levels of drugs metabolised by this enzyme, such as phenytoin and warfarin.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a woman who is experiencing tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia and is 4 days postpartum?
questions.explanation:
Postpartum Blues

(Option B)

Postpartum Depression

(Option A)

Postpartum Psychosis

(Option C)

Timing

Onset 3-5 days postpartum, resolves by days to weeks.

Within the first 6 weeks postpartum or after abortion.

Symptoms appear within 2-3 weeks postpartum and last 2-3 months.

Symptoms

Transient symptoms such as:

  • Emotionally labile
  • Insomnia
  • Weepiness/tearfulness
  • Loss of energy
  • Depressed mood
  • Loss of interest or pleasure (anhedonia)
  • Loss of appetite
  • Insomnia
  • Social withdrawal
  • Irritability
  • Suicidal thoughts

Initial symptoms: insomnia, tearfulness, mood lability, fatigue, followed by:

  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions

Risk Factors

Not specific; linked to biochemical changes.
  • Young maternal age
  • Antenatal depression
  • Family history of mood disorder
  • Unmarried status
  • Smoking
  • Stress
  • Newborns in intensive care
  • Physical or verbal abuse
  • Serious adverse obstetrical events
  • Nulliparas
  • Obstetrical complications
  • Family history of mood disorder
  • History of psychotic illness

Treatment

Supportive treatment and reassurance.

Antidepressants and psychotherapy.
  • Hospitalization, pharmacological treatment (lithium, antipsychotics, antidepressants), and long-term psychiatric care.
  • Temporary separation from the infant and nursing supervision may be necessary.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 25-year-old woman who presents with symptoms such as anxiety, palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, chest pain, and a sense of impending doom? The patient mentions having encountered approximately 5-6 comparable episodes in the last half-year, with each episode persisting for around 20-30 minutes.

A 38-year-old female presented to a psychiatrist with symptoms of low mood, loss of interest, loss of appetite, and difficulty sleeping for 2 months. The psychiatrist makes the diagnosis of a major depressive disorder. Which drug is best for the disorder, as mentioned earlier?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Flu

Major classes of medications used in treating depression

Class

Examples

Use

SSRIs

Fluoxetine, Sertraline, Escitalopram, Citalopram, Paroxetine

First-line due to safety and tolerability

SNRIs

Venlafaxine, Duloxetine

For those not responding to SSRIs

Atypical Antidepressants

Bupropion, Mirtazapine

Less sexual dysfunction (Bupropion); helps insomnia (Mirtazapine)

Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCAs)

Amitriptyline, Nortriptyline

For treatment-resistant cases

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs)

Phenelzine, Tranylcypromine

Reserved for severe, resistant depression

Adjunct Therapy

Atypical antipsychotics, Lithium

For treatment-resistant depression

Treatment Duration:

  • Acute Phase: Minimum of 6 months or length of previous episode (whichever is longer)
  • Maintenance/Prophylaxis: Indicated for 3+ episodes or chronic depression (>2 years)

questions.text: Which antidepressant would you recommend for a 38-year-old professor experiencing depression who is concerned about potential sexual dysfunction as a side effect?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Bu

Antidepressant Classes and Their Side Effects

Class

Examples

Mechanism of Action

Common Side Effects

Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs)

Fluoxetine, Escitalopram, Sertraline

Inhibit serotonin reuptake, increasing its availability
  • Nausea
  • Insomnia
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Weight gain
  • Emotional blunting

Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors (SNRIs)

Venlafaxine, Duloxetine

Inhibit reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine
  • Hypertension (dose-dependent)
  • Nausea
  • Insomnia
  • Sexual dysfunction

Atypical Antidepressants

Bupropion, Mirtazapine

Varies by drug: e.g., Bupropion (NDRI) increases norepinephrine and dopamine
  • Bupropion: Dry mouth, insomnia, low risk of sexual dysfunction
  • Mirtazapine: Sedation, weight gain

Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCAs)

Amitriptyline, Nortriptyline

Inhibit serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake; block muscarinic, histaminic, and alpha receptors
  • Sedation
  • Weight gain
  • Dry mouth
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Cardiotoxicity (in overdose)

Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors (MAOIs)

Phenelzine, Tranylcypromine

Inhibit monoamine oxidase enzyme, preventing the breakdown of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine.
  • Hypertensive crisis (with tyramine-containing foods)
  • Insomnia
  • Hypotension

Serotonin Modulators

Trazodone, Vilazodone

Modulate serotonin receptors and/or reuptake.
  • Trazodone: Sedation, priapism
  • Vilazodone: GI upset, less sexual dysfunction than SSRIs

Noradrenaline and Specific Serotonergic Antidepressants (NaSSAs)

Mirtazapine

Enhances norepinephrine and serotonin transmission by antagonising alpha-2 receptors.
  • Sedation (dose-dependent)
  • Weight gain
  • Low risk of sexual dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is the least probable in a patient prescribed with escitalopram?

questions.text: A Clinician asks a patient “how is your mood”. Patient replies by saying “ It is going up & down”. What is the phenomenon seen here?
questions.explanation:
Term Description
Tangentiality The patient gives an oblique or irrelevant answer and never reaches the point.
Derailment Sudden shifting of ideas with no logical connection between them.
Clang association Speech based on sound (rhyming/punning) rather than logical connections.
Neologism Newly invented words with idiosyncratic meaning.
